info.game_comments:
2001 International Championship semifinal game 1.
  From the Las Vegas Hilton.

(1, 1).clue: Tourbooks suggest shopping for baskets on Muindi Mbingu Street in this Kenyan capital

(2, 1).clue: Kulcha, nan & paratha are types of this from India & a Hindi knows which side his is buttered on

(3, 1).clue: This chief Norse god gave one of his own eyes to the giant Mimir for a drink from the Fountain of Wisdom

(4, 1).clue: Julio's 77th album, released in 2000, has 2 songs about this body part, "Corazon Partio" & "Dos Corazones, Dos Historias"

(5, 1).clue: In 2000 the state of Alabama voted to end a 1901 ban on this type of marriage

(6, 1).clue: Spanish for "few" or the '70s group that sang "Crazy Love"

(1, 2).clue: This capital city's Grand Palace was once home to Haile Selassie

(2, 2).clue: A type of this is the queso in a quesadilla

(3, 2).clue: Counted among this ancient people's gods were Khonsu, Amon & Ptah

(4, 2).clue: Born in 1975, this son of Julio's has become a singing superstar too

(5, 2).clue: These "wild" South Africans carried on their war with guerrilla actions against the British

(6, 2).clue: Miss Te Kanawa should know this means "left" in Java

(1, 3).clue: Founded in 332 B.C., this port city was designed by Dinocrates, architect to Alexander the Great

(2, 3).clue: It's the type of pastry dough you use when you whip up some Greek floyeres

(3, 3).clue: Name of the passionate pipe-playing god portrayed here

(4, 3).clue: On the 1984 hit "To All the Girls I've Loved Before", Julio duetted with this U.S. country music star

(5, 3).clue: On Jan. 22, 1901 the Prince of Wales succeeded to the English throne as this king

(1, 4).clue: Sudan's national museum is in this capital city

(2, 4).clue: To make this classic German-named dish, pound a veal cutlet, coat it with crumbs, then brown it in fat

(3, 4).clue: As the Aztec god of this, Huitzilopochtli must have been "hot" stuff

(4, 4).clue: "La Cumparsita" is found on Julio's album named for this South American dance

(5, 4).clue: Emil von Behring won the first Nobel Prize for Medicine with a serum against this "d"isease, a common killer

(6, 4).clue: Consisting of 2 4-letter words, this French phrase on a menu means there is a set cost for a meal

(1, 5).clue: It's the oldest of Morocco's imperial cities, & a fine place to shop for a hat

(2, 5).clue: This beef & sour cream dish is named for a Russian count

(3, 5).clue: We're not sure, but this wing-footed Roman god of commerce might be liquid at room temperature

(5, 5).clue: The world's most productive oil field was in the area of this city, now the capital of Azerbaijan

(6, 5).clue: This founder of analytical psychology will never get old

(1, 1).clue: Polish-born Jerzy Kosinski wrote all of his novels, including "Being There" in this, his adopted language

(2, 1).clue: ...who was barred from a third term as Serbian president; in 1997 was made president of Yugoslavia

(3, 1).clue: This popular tropical fruit was named for its resemblance to a pine cone

(4, 1).clue: Characters in this Bizet opera include a toreador, a gypsy girl & cigarette factory girls

(5, 1).clue: In 1968 this widow of a U.S. president married Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis

(6, 1).clue: "Red Vineyard at Arles" was possibly the only painting this Dutchman sold during his lifetime

(1, 2).clue: She based the characters of Anne & Robert in her novel "The Mandarins" on herself & Jean-Paul Sartre

(2, 2).clue: ...who became the first popularly elected head of this island in 1996, Lee Teng-hui, is a Taipei personality

(3, 2).clue: This tropical island has roads linking Port Antonio, Montego Bay & Kingston

(4, 2).clue: This Austrian composer didn't complete his operas "Adrast" & "Sakuntala"; he left a symphony "unfinished", too

(5, 2).clue: Less than a week after Princess Diana died, the world mourned the death of this beloved nun in India

(6, 2).clue: A famous Rembrandt painting shows "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of" this ancient poet

(1, 3).clue: It's the native country of Flora Nwapa, who wrote "This is Lagos, and Other Stories"

(2, 3).clue: ...who ended the ban on the ANC in South Africa in 1990

(3, 3).clue: It's the name for the parallel at 23 degrees 27 minutes south latitude

(4, 3).clue: In Offenbach's "Orphee aux Enfers", Orpheus goes to Hades to retrieve this woman, his cheatin' wife

(5, 3).clue: Previous jobs on her resume would include research chemist, lawyer & prime minister of Great Britain

(6, 3).clue: He depicted a poppy field in a hollow near Giverny in the painting seen here

(1, 4).clue: The original Italian title of this Umberto Eco novel is "Il Nome Della Rosa"

(2, 4).clue: ...who went from La Prensa to la presidencia of Nicaragua in 1990

(3, 4).clue: Large tropical rain forest regions include the Amazon & one centered on this 2,900-mile-long African river

(4, 4).clue: Verdi's "Falstaff" is based on Shakespeare's "Henry IV" plays & this Shakespeare comedy

(5, 4).clue: Italian lawmaker Alessandra Mussolini is the granddaughter of Benito Mussolini & the niece of this famous actress

(6, 4).clue: Appropriately, one of this painter's views of Toledo can be seen at his museum in Toledo, Spain

(1, 5).clue: In 2000 Turkish author Andrew Mango published a new biography of this founder of modern Turkey

(3, 5).clue: The largest country in the world entirely in the tropics is this Asian nation made up of over 13,700 islands

(4, 5).clue: A comic opera by Strauss based on an incident from his marriage, or a short orchestral piece played between scenes

(5, 5).clue: In 1988 this Karachi-born woman became the first female to head a modern Islamic country

(6, 5).clue: He's the great 16th century German artist seen here in a self-portrait

(0, 0).clue: The highest peak outside of Asia is found in this mountain range
